params.text:
Introduction

There is an ever-increasing amount of information in the world, and as the volume of information continues to grow, it is becoming more important for people to be able to differentiate between what information is real, and what is misleading. 

In both personal and professional contexts, you will need to start building the skills to identify what information is true and what is false. 

Misinformation has a long history, and this module will focus on how to understand, navigate, and contextualize the information you are encountering, especially online.

params.text:
Land Acknowledgement

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada’s final report calls for 94 actions toward restoring a balanced relationship between Indigenous peoples and settler communities in this country. 

We encourage you to not only acknowledge the traditional territory on which your institution resides, but to also ground this acknowledgement with action. 

A great resource for this is Native Land. We also suggest looking at the resources provided by the The Xwi7xwa Library, which is a centre for academic and community Indigenous scholarship. Its collections and services reflect Aboriginal approaches to teaching, learning, and research, and it is the only branch of an academic library in Canada that is entirely dedicated to Indigenous materials.

Information disorder

Information disorder syndrome is the sharing or developing of false information with or without the intent of harm. False information may be categorized as misinformation, disinformation, or malinformation (Wardle & Derakhshan, 2018).

There are emotional and ritualistic elements of communication that we cannot ignore. Much of the problematic content being shared as misinformation was initially created to foster strong emotions – most often superiority, anger, or fear. Emotional content that leans on negative emotions travels faster and more widely than information that relies on logic and fact checking. 

As future engineers you will need to navigate how to use easily available online information, and quickly make decisions about its value. This module will focus on misinformation as it relates to professional ethics, responsibility around fidelity to public needs, and devotion to personal honour and professional integrity.

params.question: Which of the following is defined as information that is false, but the person who is disseminating it believes that it is true?

params.text:
Misinformation

To reiterate, misinformation is false, misleading, or inaccurate information that is communicated regardless of an intention to deceive. That is to say, misinformation is information that is false, but the person who is disseminating it believes that it is true or believes it is clearly satire when it may not be.

Examples of misinformation may include:

  • Rumours
  • Pranks
  • Fake news
  • Satire
  • Misleading facts

Technically speaking, factual statements that are presented in a way that undermine social policy goals, instigate distrust of legitimate experts and authorities, and/or lead people towards making harmful decisions are also misinformation.

params.altText: Icon of newspaper with caution triangle at bottom and headline NEWS

params.text: A famous historical example of misinformation, as discussed by Schwartz (2016), occurred in 1938 when Orson Welles adapted H.G. Wells’ novel The War of the Worlds to be performed as a live radio broadcast. This incident became famous for causing panic amongst listeners who believed that aliens were invading the Earth, with other listeners believing they were hearing a German military invasion in real time. Though this may seem comical today, this example highlights how political tensions of the day can quickly escalate to widespread panic and misinformation.

History of misinformation

The history of misinformation dates back much further than the 1930’s. One of the earliest examples is the Vegetable Lamb of Tartary. In the 14th century, a text claiming to be the travel memoirs of an English knight, described a tree in India that grew gourd-like fruit, inside of which were tiny lambs. These claims were furthered by an Italian friar, who wrote of a similar experience 30 years earlier. As more ‘people of credence’ confirmed the tale, more people became believers, and the fruit became famous. It would take another 400 years before this story was proven to be a myth. 

 Other examples of misinformation throughout history include:

  • Great Moon Hoax
  • Dewey Defeats Truman
  • Numerous Health Fallacies
  • Conspiracy Theories

Causes & Spread of Misinformation

Misinformation spreads more quickly and is viewed by up to 100 times as many people as accurate information (Vosoughi et al., 2018). 

Misinformation is spread for a variety of reasons including: 

  • Political motivations
  • Monetary gain
  • Emotional manipulation
  • Converting popularity into legitimacy

Individual characteristics may also play a part in spreading misinformation. According to Buchanan (2020), people with the following traits tend to spread misinformation more readily:

  • Disagreeable personalities
  • Limited subject knowledge
  • A conservative political orientation

params.altText: Icon of signs, one with checkmark and one with x

params.text:
Social Media

Social Media sites (Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, etc.) have become notable as ways of spreading misinformation, and this can be notoriously difficult to spot. Misinformation, which may also be referred to as “fake news", spreads online much faster than it has historically because online tools are easy to use and lack regulation, oversight, editors, and fact checkers. Ultimately, misinformation gets clicks and social media platforms depend on clicks for continued profit. 

At the same time there is also a parallel movement at work, focused on intentionally and deliberately curbing the spread of misinformation through influencers and websites aimed at stopping the spread, debunking, or educating people.

params.altText: Icon of application icons representing Facebook, Instagram and TikTok

params.text:
How toxic information is spread

Wardle and Derakhshan (2018) establish the following framework for information toxicity, indicating how false information is generated and spreads online:

  • Creation – Misleading information is written by an unknown author.
  • Production – The article or story is published on a created “news” website, giving the story some low-level credibility.
  • Distribution - A link to the article or story is shared on social media. 
  • Re-production - Individuals for whom the information in the story confirms their viewpoint share the article or story widely on social media.

params.altText: Icon of a phone with speech bubble containing caution icon

params.text:
Identifying misinformation  

Start by thinking about the context of the information you’ve found.

Ask yourself:

• For information to be credible, the person sharing the information should have credentials that are related to the subject at hand.
  • Are they a biased source, and if so, is their bias clear?
• Is the information anecdotal or something with stronger evidence?

• What is the motivation for sharing this information?
  • Are they trying to sell something, are they trying to generate fear or distrust of something?

Information integrity

Identifying false information also involves considering the integrity of the information you’ve found.

When considering information shared online, it is important to look for (Buchanan, 2020):

  • False Connections
  • Misleading Content
  • False Content
  • Imposter Content
  • Manipulated Content

It is possible that the information started out as authentic but was compromised in some way.

Example

WHO image: Framework for Toxicity (Berger, 2017):

https://en.unesco.org/sites/default/files/fake_news_berger.pdf

Expertise

Many individuals rely on expertise as a proxy for quality, but in reality, expertise is one of many criteria you should consider.

When examining expertise consider the following factors (Posetti, 2018):

  • Value
  • Insight
  • Experience
  • Context

You must evaluate expertise within each specific context and make choices about what is appropriate based on the value and insight of the information coupled with the author’s experience and how it fits the context.

Experts in one context might be highly experienced individuals in a field, or employees of a related government office. In other settings, it might exclusively mean someone with an applicable academic (PhD) or professional (P.Eng.) credential.

Bias

Every piece of information has a bias to it. Bias is not necessarily bad, as long as you begin, and continue to question your own biases.

The Cambridge Dictionary (2021) defines bias as, “the action of supporting or opposing a particular person or thing in an unfair way, because of allowing personal opinions to influence your judgement.”

Information is created by people or by machines programmed by people; therefore, all information is biased in one way or another. As an engineer, your responsibility is to identify and navigate your own biases and the biases of the information you choose to use in your work.

params.text:
Trust and Engineering

Professional engineers must uphold professional and ethical standards. As an ethical body, engineering values truth, honesty, and trustworthiness, and expects engineers to embody these traits (Engineers Canada, 2016). The way you use and share information impacts how trustworthy you appear to others.

In a world where our personal and professional lives are so intertwined online, thinking critically about what information you share and the message it communicates is more crucial than ever. Something as simple as sharing an internet meme may seem inconsequential or humorous but can create a negative impression and erode trust. 

If you start sharing information that is wrong, you ultimately start to erode people’s trust in you, both individually and as a representative of your profession.

params.altText: Icon of computer screen with caution icon in front of screen

params.text:
By now, you are probably aware that using unreliable information in your work could cause harm to others, but this harm is not always as obvious as a bridge or building collapse. Take the development of algorithms and AI for example. The quality of your programming and its potential outcomes are all dependent on your ability to know what is right, use quality information, acknowledge bias, and act ethically.

As a future engineer, you are only as knowledgeable as the information you use. Using credible, reliable information in both personal and professional settings, helps build and promote public trust and confidence in engineers as educated, ethical professionals.

params.altText: Icon of computer screen with exclamation mark covering screen

params.text:
Preserving Trust

To preserve public trust in you as an individual and as a representative of the engineering profession, you must take the time to ensure that you are not using or sharing misinformation.

params.altText: Engineer avatar with hard hat standing in a neutral pose

params.text: Fact checking the information can help you determine whether or not it is false or misleading. However, fact checking can be difficult and time-consuming. Fact checking websites may help, but their insights often come too late and may be tainted with biases of their own. For more information on strategies for evaluating information, see the Engineering Literacy module, “Information Evaluation and Filtering.”

When finding information online, one of the best ways to protect against misinformation is to think about why the author(s) posted the information. Considering the author’s intentions can help you see their motivations and point out their biases.

This strategy is useful whether you’re searching for information on vaccine safety or using code already created on Stack Exchange.
Remember, to build good habits around finding any information, you have to practice them with all information.

params.text:
Final thoughts

As an engineer, your decisions around information impact not only you, but other engineers around the world, and contribute to commonly held beliefs and trust toward the profession as a whole.

Misinformation can be difficult to spot and if you aren’t careful, it can be easy to use and spread false information unintentionally, potentially damaging your personal and professional reputation.

As a student, you can get in the habit of assessing the motives, context, and biases of information you encounter now, to start building the skills that will help you identify and avoid misinformation.

Further Reading:

  • The Misinformation Age: How False Beliefs Spread by Cailin O’Connor & James Owen Weatherall
  • The Death of Expertise: The Campaign against Established Knowledge and Why it Matters by Tom Nichols
  • The Information: A history, A Theory, A Flood by James Gleick

Graduate attributes

3.1.2 Problem analysis: An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

3.1.3 Investigation: An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

3.1.7 Communication skills: An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large. Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.

3.1.8 Professionalism: An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.

3.1.10 Ethics and equity: An ability to apply professional ethics, accountability, and equity.

3.1.12 Life-long learning: An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.
